Situation1: They briefly mention their day during a casual conversation at home.
Expectation2: Wash and condition clients' hair before cutting or styling
Situation2: Heavy product buildup is causing tight tangles that will impede scissors.
Story: I sat across from my partner at the kitchen table, swirling my tea, half-listening as they recounted a frustrating moment at work. I knew I should be more present, ask questions, show I cared. That’s what we promised each other—open communication, no matter how tired or distracted we felt. But my mind kept drifting back to the salon, to the last client of the day. Her hair was a mess of product buildup, so tangled I could barely get my fingers through it. I’d have to wash and condition it thoroughly before I could even think about cutting, but she was already running late and seemed impatient. I felt the pressure to keep the schedule moving, to not fall behind for the next client. Now, at home, I was supposed to be attentive, supportive, but all I could think about was the knot of hair and the knot in my stomach. My partner’s voice faded into the background as I wrestled with the demands of both worlds, unsure which one needed me more in this moment.
